summary: This document is a news article reporting on a legal filing by JPMorgan Chase attorney Felecia Ellsworth, who argues that the U.S. Virgin Islands (USVI) government is improperly blocking the release of public records related to Jeffrey Epstein. The bank claims the records are being withheld not due to confidentiality but because they are embarrassing to government officials who had dealings with Epstein. The article details the ongoing lawsuit where the USVI government is suing JPMorgan for keeping Epstein as a client, and the bank is countering that USVI officials were aware of Epstein's activities.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Accused sex offender, former JPMorgan client
persons.context: Central figure in the lawsuit; deceased financier whose banking relationship and criminal activities are the subject of the legal dispute between JPMorgan and the USVI government.

persons.name: Felecia Ellsworth
persons.context: JPMorgan's lawyer who filed the memorandum arguing against the USVI government's confidentiality claims and seeking to unseal records about Epstein.

persons.name: Linda Singer
persons.context: Filed a memorandum on behalf of the USVI government that included partially redacted exhibits related to Epstein.

persons.name: Jed Rakoff
persons.context: The judge presiding over the case, to whom Ellsworth's letter was addressed.

persons.name: Kenneth Mapp
persons.role: Former Governor of the U.S. Virgin Islands
persons.context: His administration received the 2015 'Black Hole Award' for lack of government transparency.

persons.name: Albert Bryan Jr.
persons.role: Governor of the U.S. Virgin Islands
persons.context: Current governor whose administration is accused of using similar tactics to withhold public records related to Epstein; signed off on renewal of Epstein's tax benefit certificate in 2013.

persons.name: Cecile de Jongh
persons.role: Former First Lady of the U.S. Virgin Islands
persons.context: Reportedly worked as Epstein's employee for 20 years and had close contact with him.

persons.name: Stacy Plaskett
persons.context: Acknowledged in a deposition that she met privately with Epstein several times to solicit campaign contributions; served as V.I. Economic Development Authority attorney from 2007-2012.

persons.name: Suzanne Carlson
persons.context: Author of the news article reporting on the court filing.

connections.description: Bryan, as EDA chairman and later Governor, signed off on the renewal of Epstein's tax benefit certificate in 2013, granting him millions in tax exemptions.
Plaskett met privately with Epstein several times to solicit campaign contributions while she was V.I. Economic Development Authority attorney.
de Jongh worked as Epstein's employee for 20 years and had close contact with him.
Ellsworth (JPMorgan attorney) and Singer (USVI government attorney) are opposing counsel in the lawsuit over Epstein-related records.
Epstein was a client of JPMorgan Chase, which is being sued by the USVI for keeping him as a client despite knowledge of his activities.
The USVI government granted Epstein tax exemptions for years and officials had dealings with him, while now suing JPMorgan over his banking.

events.title: Epstein's Florida conviction
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was convicted of child sex crimes in Florida.

events.title: Renewal of Epstein's tax benefits
events.description: Governor Albert Bryan Jr. signed off on the renewal of Epstein's tax benefit certificate, continuing millions in tax exemptions.

events.title: Epstein's death
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein died by suicide in August 2019 while awaiting trial on new charges.

events.title: Stacy Plaskett deposition
events.description: VI. Delegate Stacy Plaskett acknowledged in a deposition that she met privately with Epstein several times to solicit campaign contributions.

events.title: JPMorgan's opposition filing
events.description: JPMorgan's lawyers tried to file exhibits publicly since May 23, but were blocked by USVI government confidentiality claims.

events.title: Scheduled Bryan deposition
events.description: Governor Albert Bryan Jr. was scheduled to be deposed on June 6, but the transcript has not been publicly released.

keyFacts: JPMorgan Chase is defending against a lawsuit by the USVI government which claims the bank kept Epstein as a client despite knowledge of his suspicious transactions and abuse allegations.

JPMorgan's attorney, Felecia Ellsworth, argues the USVI government is blocking the release of public records not due to confidentiality, but because they are embarrassing to officials who dealt with Epstein.
The USVI government granted Epstein millions in tax exemptions for years, with Governor Albert Bryan Jr. signing a renewal in 2013, despite Epstein being a convicted sex offender.
Several USVI officials, including former First Lady Cecile de Jongh and Congresswoman Stacy Plaskett, had close contact or financial dealings with Epstein.
The article highlights a pattern of lack of transparency by the USVI government, which received the 2015 'Black Hole Award' for contempt of public records laws.
